title:
On the Lusternik-Schnirelmann category of spaces with 2-dimensional
  fundamental group

title_detail.value:
On the Lusternik-Schnirelmann category of spaces with 2-dimensional
  fundamental group

summary:
The following inequality
  \cat X\le \cat Y+\lceil\frac{hd(X)-r}{r+1}\rceil
  holds for every locally trivial fibration between $ANE$ spaces $f:X\to Y$
which admits a section and has the $r$-connected fiber where $hd(X)$ is the
homotopical dimension of $X$. We apply this inequality to prove that
  \cat X\le \lceil\frac{\dim X-1}{2}\rceil+cd(\pi_1(X))
  for every complex $X$ with $cd(\pi_1(X))\le 2$.

summary_detail.value:
The following inequality
  \cat X\le \cat Y+\lceil\frac{hd(X)-r}{r+1}\rceil
  holds for every locally trivial fibration between $ANE$ spaces $f:X\to Y$
which admits a section and has the $r$-connected fiber where $hd(X)$ is the
homotopical dimension of $X$. We apply this inequality to prove that
  \cat X\le \lceil\frac{\dim X-1}{2}\rceil+cd(\pi_1(X))
  for every complex $X$ with $cd(\pi_1(X))\le 2$.

author: A. Dranishnikov
fulltext:
arXiv:0709.4018v1 [math.GT] 25 Sep 2007

ON THE LUSTERNIK-SCHNIRELMANN CATEGORY
OF SPACES WITH
2-DIMENSIONAL FUNDAMENTAL GROUP
ALEXANDER N. DRANISHNIKOV
Abstract. The following inequality


hd(X) − r
catLS X ≤ catLS Y +
r+1
holds for every locally trivial fibration between AN E spaces f :
X → Y which admits a section and has the r-connected fiber
where hd(X) is the homotopical dimension of X. We apply this
inequality to prove that


dim X − 1
catLS X ≤
+ cd(π1 (X))
2
for every complex X with cd(π1 (X)) ≤ 2.

1. Introduction
In [DKR] we proved that if the Lusternik-Schnirelmann category of a
closed n-manifold, n ≥ 3, equals 2 then the fundamental group of M is
free. In opposite direction we proved that if the fundamental group of
an n-manifold is free, then catLS M ≤ n−2. Then J. Strom proved that
catLS X ≤ 32 n for every n-complex, n > 4, with free fundamental group
[St]. Yu. Rudyak suggested that the coefficient 2/3 in Strom's result
should be improved to 1/2. Precisely, he conjectured that the function
f defined as f (n) = max{catLS M n } is asymptotically 21 n where the
maximum is taken over all closed n-manifolds with free fundamental
group.
In this paper we prove Rudyak's conjecture. Our method gives the
same estimate for n-complexes. Moreover, it gives the same asymptotic
upper bound for catLS of n-complexes with the fundamental group of
cohomological dimension ≤ 2. In view of this the following generalization of Rudyak's conjecture seems to be natural.
CONJECTURE. For every k the function fk defined as
fk (n) = max{catLS M n | cd(π1 (M n ) ≤ k}
is asymptotically 21 n.

1

 2

A. DRANISHNIKOV

The smallest k when it is unknown is 3.
The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 is an introduction to
the Lusternik-Schnirelmann category based on an analogy with the
dimension theory. Section 3 contains a version of a fibration theorem
for catLS . In Section 4 this fibration theorem is applied for the proof
of Rudyak's conjecture.
2. Kolmogorov-Ostrand's approach to the
Lusternik-Schnirelmann category
An open cover U = {Ui } of a topological space X is called Xcontractible if each Ui can be contracted to a point in X. By the
definition catLS X ≤ n if there is an X-contractible cover of X by n + 1
elements.
We recall [CLOT] that a sequence ∅ = O0 ⊂ O1 ⊂ * * * ⊂ On+1 = X is
called categorical of length n + 1 if each difference Oi+1 \ Oi is contained
in an open set that contracts to a point. It was proven in [CLOT] that
catLS X ≤ n if and only if X admits a categorical sequence of length
n + 1.
Let U be a family of open set in a topological space X. The multiplicity of U (or the order) at a point x ∈ X, Ordx U is the number
of elements of U that contain x. The multiplicity of U is defined as
Ord U = supx∈X Ordx U. We recall that the covering dimension of a
topological space X does not exceed n, dim X ≤ n, if for every open
cover C of X there is an open refinement U with Ord U ≤ n + 1.
The following proposition makes the LS-category analogous to the
covering dimension.
2.1. Proposition. For a paracompact topological space X, catLS X ≤ n
if and only if X admits an X-contractible locally finite open cover V
with OrdV ≤ n + 1.
Proof. If catLS X ≤ n then by the definition X admits an open contractible cover that consists of n + 1 elements and therefore its multiplicity is at most n + 1.
Let V be a contractible cover of X of multiplicity ≤ n + 1. We
construct a categorical sequence O0 ⊂ O1 ⊂ * * * ⊂ On+1 of length n+ 1.
We define O1 = {x ∈ X | Ordx V} = n + 1. Note that O1 = ∪Vi ∈V V0 ∩
* * * ∩ Vn . Note that this is the disjoint union and every nonempty
summand is X-contractible. Thus O1 is X-contractible. Next, we
define O2 = {x ∈ X | Ordx V ≥ n}. Then O2 \ O1 = cupVi ∈V (V1 ∩ * * * ∩
Vn \ O1 ) is a disjoint union of closed in O2 subsets. Since this family
is locally finite, we can take open (in O2 and hence in X) disjoint
neighborhoods of these summands V1 ∩ * * * ∩ Vn \ O1 such that each of

 ON THE LUSTERNIK-SCHNIRELMANN CATEGORY OF SPACES WITH2-DIMENSIONAL FUNDAMENTAL GR

which is contained in an open contractible set from V. Define O3 =
{x ∈ X | Ordx ≥ n − 1} as the union of n − 1-fold intersections and so
on. On+1 is the union of elements of V (1-fold intersections) and hence
On+1 = X. Clearly, for every k, Ok+1 \ Ok is the union of disjoint sets
each of which is contained in an element of V. Thus, the categorical
sequence conditions are satisfied.

A family U of subsets of X is called a k-cover, k ∈ N if every
subfamily of k elements form a cover of X. The following is obvious.
2.2. Proposition. A family U of m-elements is an (n + 1)-cover of X
if and only if Ordx U ≥ m − n for all x ∈ X.
Proof. If Ordx U < m−n for some x ∈ X, then n+ 1 = m−(m−n) + 1
elements of U do not cover x.
If n + 1 elements of U do not cover some x, then Ordx U ≤ m − (n +
1) < m − n.

Inspired by the work of Kolmogorov on Hilbert's 13 problem Ostrand
gave the following characterization of the covering dimension [Os].
2.3. Theorem (Ostrand). A metric space X is of dimension ≤ n if
and only if for each open cover C of X and each integer m ≥ n + 1,
there exist m discrete families of open sets U1 , * * * , Uk such that their
union ∪Ui is an (n + 1)-cover of X.
Let U be a family of subsets in X and let A ⊂ X. We denote by
U|A − {U ∩ A | U ∈ U}.
2.4. Definition. Let f : X → Y be a map. An open cover U =
{U0 , U1 , . . . , Un } of X is called uniformly f -contractible if it satisfies
the property that for every y ∈ Y there is a neighborhood V such
that the restriction U|f −1 (V ) of U to the preimage f −1 (V ) consists of
X-contractible sets.
2.5. Theorem. Let {U0′ , . . . , Un′ } be an open cover of a normal topological space X. Then there is an infinite open (n + 1)-cover of X,
′
n
{Uk }∞
k=0 such that Uk = Uk for k ≤ n and Uk = ∪i=0 Vi is the disjoint
union with Vi ⊂ Ui for k > n.
In particular, if {U0′ , . . . , Un′ } is X-contractible, the cover {Uk }∞
k=0
is X-contractible. If {U0′ , . . . , Un′ } is uniformly f -contractible for some
f : X → Y , the cover {Uk }∞
k=0 is uniformly f -contractible.
Proof. By induction on m we construct the family {Ui }m
i=0 . For m = n
we take Ui = Ui′ .
Let U = {U0 , . . . , Um } be the corresponding family for m ≥ n. Consider Y = {x ∈ X | Ordx U ≤ m − n}. In view of Proposition 2.2 and

A. DRANISHNIKOV

the assumption, it is a closed subset. We show that for every i ≤ n,
the set Y ∩ Ui is closed in X. Let x be a limit point of Y ∩ Ui that
does not belong to Ui . Let Ui0 , . . . , Uim−n be the elements that contain
x. Then Ordy U = m − n + 1 for all y ∈ Y ∩ Ui ∩ Ui0 ∩ * * * ∩ Uim−n .
Contradiction.
We define recursively F0 = Y ∩ U1 and Fi+1 = Y ∩ Ui+1 \ (∪ik=0 Ui ).
Note that {Fi } is a disjoint finite family of closed subsets. We fix
disjoint open neighborhoods Vi of Fi with Vi ⊂ Ui . We define Um+1 =
∪i Vi . In view of Proposition 2.2, U1 , . . . , Um , Um+1 is an (n + 1)-cover.
Clearly, if all Ui are X-contractible, i ≤ n, then Um+1 is X-contractible.
If all Ui are uniformly f -contractible, for some f : X → Y , then Um+1
is uniformly f -contractible.

2.6. Corollary. For a normal topological space X, catLS X ≤ n if and
only if for any m > n X admits an open (n+1)-cover by X-contractible
sets.
This corollary is a catLS -analog of Ostrand's theorem. It also can be
found in [CLOT] with further reference to [Cu].
3. Fibration theorems for catLS
3.1. Definition. The ∗-category catLS ∗ f of a map f : X → Y is the
minimal n, if exists, such that there is a uniformly f -contractible open
cover U = {U0 , U1 , . . . , Un } of X.
Note that catLS ∗ c = catLS X for a constant map c : X → pt. More
generally, catLS ∗ π = catLS X for the projection π : X × Y → Y .
3.2. Theorem. The inequality catLS X ≤ dim Y + catLS ∗ f holds true
for any continuous map.
Proof. The requirements to the spaces in the theorem are that the
Ostrand theorem holds true for Y , i.e. are fairly general (say, Y is
normal).
Let dim Y = n and catLS ∗ f = m. Let U = {U0 , . . . Um } be a uniformly f -contractible cover. For all y ∈ Y denote by Vy a neighborhood of y from the definition of the uniform f -contractibility. In
view of Ostrand's characterization of dimension there is a refinement
V = V0 ∪* * *∪Vn+m of the cover {Vy | y ∈ Y } such that each family Vi is
disjoint. Let Vi = ∪Vi . We apply Theorem 2.5 to extend the family U
to a family {U0 , . . . , Un+m }. Consider the family W = {f −1 (Vi ) ∩ Ui }.
Note that it is contractible in X. We show that it is a cover of X.
According to the Ostrand theorem every y ∈ Y is covered by m + 1
elements Vi0 , . . . , Vim . By Theorem 2.5 the family Ui0 , . . . , Uim covers
the fiber f −1 (y).


 ON THE LUSTERNIK-SCHNIRELMANN CATEGORY OF SPACES WITH2-DIMENSIONAL FUNDAMENTAL GR

3.3. Corollary (Corollary 9.35 [CLOT], [OW]). Let p : X → Y be a
closed map of ANE. If each fiber p−1 (y) is contractible in X, then
catLS X ≤ dim Y .
Proof. In this case catLS ∗ p = 0. Indeed, since X is an ANE, a contraction of p−1 (y) to a point can be extended to a neighborhood U.
Since the map p is closed there is a neighborhood V of y such that
p−1 (V ) ⊂ U.


We recall that the homotopical dimension of a space X, hd(X), is
the minimal dimension of a CW -complex homotopy equivalent to X
[CLOT].
The elementary obstruction theory implies the following.
3.4. Proposition. Let p : E → X be a fibration with n − 1-connected
fiber where n = hd(X). Then p admits a section.
We recall that ⌈x⌉ denotes the smallest integer n such that x ≤ n.
3.5. Theorem. Suppose that a locally trivial fibration f : X → Y with
an r-connected fiber F admits a section. Then

Moreover,

Proof. Let catLS Y = m and hd(X) = n.
Let s : Y → X be a section. We apply the fiber-wise Serre construction to f with this s(y) as the base points. Then we apply the
fiber-wise Ganea construction to obtain a map ξk : Ek → X. Namely,
E0 = {φ ∈ X I | |f (φ(I))| = 1, φ(0) = sf φ(I)}
with ξ0 (φ) = φ(1) and
Ek+1 = {φ ∗ ψ ∈ E0 ∗ Ek | ξ0 (φ) = ξk (ψ)}
with the natural projection ξk+1 : Ek+1 → X. Note that ξk is a
Hurewicz fibration with the fiber the join product ∗k+1 ΩF of k + 1
copies of the loop space ΩF . Thus, it is (k +(k +1)r −1)-connected. By
Proposition 3.4 there is a section σ : X → Ek whenever k(r+1)+r ≥ n.
The smallest such k is equal to ⌈ gcd(X)−r

A. DRANISHNIKOV

We use the notation σ(x)i = ti . Clearly, σ(x)i is a continuous function.
A section σ : X → Ek defines a cover U = {U0 , . . . , Uk } of X as
follows:
Ui = {x ∈ X | σ(x)i > 0}.
Let {U0 , . . . , Um+k } be an extension of U to an (k + 1)-cover of X from
Theorem 2.5.
Let V = {V0 , . . . Vm+k } be an open Y -contractible (m + 1)-cover of
Y . We show that the sets Wi = f −1 (Vi ) ∩ Ui are contractible in X
for all i. By the construction of Ui for i ≤ n for every x ∈ Ui there
is a canonical path connecting x with sf (x). We use these paths to
contract f −1 (Vi ) ∩ Ui to s(Vi ) in X. Then we apply a contraction of
s(Vi ) to a point in s(Y ). If i > k, we apply the last condition of the
first part of Theorem 2.5.
Similarly as in the proof of Theorem 3.2 we show that {Wi }m+k
i=0 is
a cover of X. Since V is an (m + 1)-cover, by Proposition 2.2 every
y ∈ Y is covered by at least k + 1 elements Vi0 , . . . , Vik of V. By the
construction Ui0 , . . . , Uik is a cover of X. Hence Wi0 , . . . , Wik covers
f −1 (y).

4. The Lusternik-Schnirelmann category of complexes
with low dimensional fundamental groups
4.1. Theorem. For every complex X with cd(π1 (X)) ≤ 2 the following
inequality holds true:


hd(X) − 1
catLS X ≤ cd(π1 (X)) +

We claim that there is a section s : Bπ → X̃ ×π Eπ of f . By the
condition cdπ ≤ 2 we may assume that Bπ is a complex of dimension
≤ 3. Since a fiber of f is simply connected, there is a lift of the 2skeleton. The condition cdπ ≤ 2 implies H 3 (Bπ, E) = 0 for every
π-module. Thus, we have no obstruction for the lift of the 3-skeleton.
We apply Theorem 3.5 to obtain the inequality

Since g is a fibration with the homotopy trivial fiber, the space X̃ ×π Eπ
is homotopy equivalent to X. Thus, hd(X̃ ×π Eπ) = hd(X). Note that
catLS Bπ = cdπ.

4.2. Corollary. For every complex X with free fundamental group:

2
Note that this estimate is sharp on X = S 1 × CP n .

4.3. Corollary. For every 3-dimensional complex X with free fundamental group: catLS X ≤ 2.
This Corollary can be also derived from the fact that in the case of
free fundamental group every 2-complex is homotopy equivalent to the
wedge of circles and 2-spheres [KR].
It is unclear whether the estimate catLS X ≤ 2 + ⌈ dim 2X−1 ⌉ is sharp
for complexes with cd(π1 (X)) = 2. It is sharp when the answer to the
following question is affirmative.
4.4. Question. Does there exists a 4-complex K with free fundamental
group and with catLS (K × S 1 ) = 4?
⌉.
Indeed, for X = K × S 1 we would have the equality 4 = 2 + ⌈ 5−1
2
Note that cd(π( X)) = 2. There is a connection between this question
and the Problem 1.5 from [DKR] which asks whether catLS M 4 ≤ 2 for
closed 4-manifolds with free fundamental group.
